question.content:
A cross-section of an equipotential surface around a positive point charge is shown below. 

[[☃ image 1]]

It's an egg-shape instead of being perfectly round.

**Which of the following are possible explanations?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: There's a positive charge to its right.
There's a positive charge to its left.
There's a negative charge to its right.
There's a negative charge to its left.

hints.content:
##Strategy

An equipotential surface is perpendicular to the electric field at every point.

Let's pick any choice, draw the electric field lines by hand as accurately as we can, and see if we can construct an equipotential surface around our negative charge.

##Solution

- *[Check out this video](https://www.khanacademy.org/science/in-in-class-12th-physics-india/in-in-electrostatic-potential-and-capacitance/x51bd77206da864f3:equipotential-surfaces/v/equipotential-surfaces-why-they-are-perpendicular-to-field) to understand deeply why equipotential surfaces are always perpendicular to the electric field at every point.*

- *[Check out this video](https://www.khanacademy.org/science/in-in-class-12th-physics-india/in-in-electrostatic-potential-and-capacitance/x51bd77206da864f3:equipotential-surfaces/v/equipotential-surfaces-of-two-charges-dipoles) to understand how equipotential surfaces look when multiple charges are present.*

----

If we apply the principle here, we find the following two correct scenarios.

- A positive charge to its left:    

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/7365d027674e2a51d96572c4369c9b70f42c4e5f.png)

- A negative charge to its right:

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/3d7f983ca349f2a35f3e4cd0b81b053240fea6cc.png)

The correct answers are:

- There's a positive charge to its left.

- There's a negative charge to its right.
